item.title: SpaceX and xAI in merger talks ahead of potential record IPO
item.description:
Elon Musk's SpaceX and xAI are in negotiations regarding a potential merger ahead of what could become the largest initial public offering in history, according to exclusive reporting by Reuters.

The merger would unite Musk's aerospace empire with his artificial intelligence venture, consolidating the Starlink satellite network, the X social media platform, and the Grok AI chatbot under a single corporate structure. Reuters reported that two Nevada entities were established on January 21 to facilitate the transaction, with SpaceX Chief Financial Officer Bret Johnsen listed as a managing member in corporate filings.

item.title: Cuba's oil reserves down to 15-20 days as U.S. pressure mounts
item.description:
Cuba's oil reserves have dwindled to a level that will sustain the island for only 15 to 20 days, according to data from energy analytics firm Kpler, as U.S. pressure on traditional suppliers threatens to push the nation toward economic collapse.

The crisis has deepened rapidly following the Trump administration's January 3 military operation that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, effectively severing Cuba's primary oil lifeline. Venezuela, which supplied roughly a third of Cuba's oil at approximately 26,500 barrels per day in 2025, has not shipped any crude or fuel to the Caribbean island since early January.

item.title: Nvidia, Microsoft and Amazon in talks to invest $60B in OpenAI
item.description:
Nvidia, Microsoft and Amazon are in discussions to invest up to $60 billion in OpenAI, according to a report by The Information published Wednesday. The talks, if they lead to a deal, would be one of the largest private financings ever for an AI company and would further entangle the world’s biggest technology suppliers in the scramble for computing power and market share in generative AI.

The negotiations are ongoing and terms could change, and Reuters said it could not immediately verify The Information’s reporting. Still, the report fits a widening fundraising push around OpenAI that has drawn in major strategic backers and deep pools of global capital.

item.title: Apple posts record quarter as iPhone sales surge 23%
item.description:
Apple delivered what CEO Tim Cook called a "remarkable, record-breaking quarter" on Thursday, posting fiscal first-quarter results that far exceeded Wall Street expectations as iPhone sales surged 23% year-over-year to drive the company's best holiday period ever.

The tech giant reported revenue of $143.8 billion for the quarter ending December 27, up 16% from the prior year and well ahead of analyst estimates of $138.4 billion. Earnings per share reached $2.84, a 19% increase that set a new all-time record and topped the $2.67 consensus forecast.

item.title: Amazon in talks to invest up to $50 billion in OpenAI
item.description:
Amazon.com, Inc. is negotiating a potential investment of up to $50 billion in OpenAI, according to a report from The Wall Street Journal on Thursday, a deal that would represent one of the largest bets yet on artificial intelligence and deepen ties between the world's largest cloud-computing provider and the maker of ChatGPT.

Amazon CEO Andy Jassy is personally leading the discussions with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, sources familiar with the matter told The Wall Street Journal and CNBC. The final structure of any potential deal remains fluid, though a term sheet could be finalized in the coming weeks, according to CNBC.

item.title: Gold surges to record high near $5,600 for ninth straight session
item.description: World stocks gained on Thursday as investors maintained their appetite for equities ahead of Apple results, while gold climbed to a record high for the ninth consecutive session. The rally in precious metals, coupled with strong corporate guidance from Meta, provided support across global markets despite concerns over tech sector capital expenditure.

item.title: Venezuela approves law ending 20 years of state oil control
item.description:
Venezuela's National Assembly on Thursday approved a sweeping reform to the country's hydrocarbons law, ending more than two decades of state control over the nation's oil sector and opening the door to private investment in the world's largest proven crude reserves.

The vote marks a dramatic departure from the socialist economic model that has governed Venezuela since former President Hugo Chávez nationalized the industry in the mid-2000s. The legislation comes less than a month after the U.S. military captured then-President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas on January 3.

item.title: Trump says he plans to talk to Iran amid naval buildup
item.description:
President Donald Trump confirmed on Thursday that he is planning to hold direct talks with Iran as tensions between Washington and Tehran escalate, pairing diplomatic signals with warnings about the naval forces now positioned near the Islamic Republic.

"I have had and I am planning on it," Trump told reporters at the Kennedy Center when asked about potential discussions with Iran. He simultaneously emphasized the military pressure, stating, "We have a lot of very big, very powerful ships sailing to Iran right now, and it would be great if we didn't have to use them".

Speaking to CBS News on Thursday, Trump revealed he has communicated two key demands to Iran in recent conversations: "No. 1, no nuclear. And No. 2, stop killing protesters".

item.title: NASA simulations reveal magnetic chaos before neutron stars collide
item.description:
NASA researchers have unveiled supercomputer simulations that provide an unprecedented view into the chaotic magnetic interactions between neutron stars in the final moments before they collide, identifying potential electromagnetic signals that future observatories could detect.

The new findings, announced by NASA on January 29, offer scientists their most detailed look yet at how the magnetospheres—highly magnetized, plasma-filled regions surrounding neutron stars—behave as the city-sized stellar remnants spiral toward a cataclysmic merger. The research, led by Dimitrios Skiathas, a graduate student at the University of Patras in Greece conducting work at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, was published in The Astrophysical Journal.

item.title: Harvard scientist proposes global network to detect interstellar objects
item.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, which has been traversing our solar system since its discovery in July 2025, continues to reveal unusual features that have prompted scientists to propose a global early warning network for detecting future visitors from beyond our cosmic neighborhood.

A new scientific proposal led by Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb and co-authored with graduate researcher Oem Trivedi outlines what they describe as the Comprehensive Interstellar Objects Network, or CISON. The framework argues that humanity is currently underprepared to detect and respond to fast-moving objects arriving from interstellar space.

item.title: NASA begins critical Artemis II fueling test ahead of moon launch
item.description:
Two days after families gathered at Kennedy Space Center to mark the 40th anniversary of the Challenger disaster, NASA is pressing forward with final preparations for Artemis II, which will send astronauts around the Moon for the first time since 1972.

The space agency began wet dress rehearsal operations on Thursday evening at Launch Pad 39B, a critical fueling test that will determine whether the mission can proceed toward its targeted launch date of February 6. The test involves loading more than 700,000 gallons of cryogenic propellants into the Space Launch System rocket and running a simulated countdown.

item.title: UBS lifts gold forecast to $6,200 as prices hit record highs
item.description:
UBS has increased its gold price target to $6,200 per ounce for March, June, and September 2026, up from its previous forecast of $5,000, citing stronger-than-expected demand stemming from increased investment flows and central bank buying.

The upgrade came as spot gold surged to an all-time high of $5,594.82 on Thursday, extending a remarkable rally that has seen the precious metal climb more than 27% since the beginning of the year. The safe-haven metal has now achieved record highs for nine consecutive sessions.

item.title: MIT engineers build silicon chips that compute with waste heat
item.description:
Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have engineered microscopic silicon structures capable of performing mathematical calculations using waste heat rather than electricity, achieving more than 99 percent accuracy in matrix multiplication operations fundamental to machine learning.

The findings, published January 29 in Physical Review Applied, represent a proof of concept for "thermal analog computing" that could enable more energy-efficient electronics by transforming a liability into a computational asset.

item.title: Airbus defense chief warns EU red tape threatens space ambitions
item.description:
Europe's three aerospace giants—Airbus, Leonardo, and Thales—are moving toward creating a unified European space company as the continent races to compete with American rivals and close what industry leaders describe as a widening capability gap.

The companies signed a Memorandum of Understanding in October 2025 to merge their space operations into a single entity that would employ approximately 25,000 people and generate about €6.5 billion in annual revenue. The venture, expected to become operational in 2027 pending regulatory approvals, would see Airbus hold a 35% stake while Leonardo and Thales each take 32.5%.

item.title: SpaceX launches free satellite collision-tracking system
item.description:
SpaceX announced Thursday night the launch of Stargaze, a new Space Situational Awareness system designed to help satellite operators avoid collisions in Earth's increasingly congested orbit. The company said it will make the collision-tracking data available to all satellite operators free of charge via its space-traffic management platform in the coming weeks.

"SpaceX is now providing precise positional awareness of objects in Earth orbit to all satellite operators for free," CEO Elon Musk wrote on X. "This will greatly reduce the probability of collisions that create orbital debris (space junk) hazards."

item.title: NASA finds ammonia on Europa, boosting hopes for habitability
item.description:
Scientists have discovered ammonia-bearing compounds on the surface of Jupiter's moon Europa for the first time, NASA announced Thursday, a finding that has prompted renewed optimism about the icy world's potential to harbor life.

The discovery emerged from re-analysis of decades-old data collected by NASA's Galileo spacecraft, which studied the Jupiter system between 1995 and 2003. Researcher Al Emran of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California detected faint signals of ammonia near fractures on Europa's frozen surface by examining data from the mission's Near-Infrared Mapping Spectrometer instrument captured during Galileo's 11th orbit of Jupiter in 1997.

item.title: NASA delays Artemis II test as arctic cold grips Florida
item.description: NASA has rescheduled the Artemis II mission's final pre-launch test due to an unusual arctic outbreak affecting Florida, pushing the earliest possible launch date to Sunday, February 8. The mission will mark humanity's first crewed voyage toward the Moon in 54 years, with Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen becoming the first non-American to journey to lunar space.

item.title: Eurozone posts best year since 2022 as Q4 growth beats forecasts
item.description:
The eurozone economy closed out 2025 with a better-than-expected quarterly expansion, but economists warn that the surging euro poses fresh challenges for the bloc's export-dependent industries.

According to preliminary data released Thursday by Eurostat, the European Union's statistics agency, gross domestic product in the 21 countries using the euro grew 0.3% in the fourth quarter of 2025, matching the prior quarter's pace and exceeding market expectations of 0.2%. For the full year, the eurozone expanded 1.5%, its strongest performance since 2022 and well above the European Commission's 1.3% projection.

item.title: IAEA holds emergency session on Ukraine nuclear safety threats
item.description:
The International Atomic Energy Agency held a special session Friday to address growing nuclear safety concerns in Ukraine, with IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi declaring that the conflict there "remains the greatest threat to nuclear safety globally."

The urgent four-hour meeting of the IAEA's Board of Governors was convened in Vienna at the request of the Netherlands with support from 11 other countries—Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Portugal, Romania, and the United Kingdom. The gathering came in response to weeks of Russian attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure that have left millions of citizens without power during winter while threatening nuclear facilities.

item.title: New map reveals Milky Way's magnetic field far more complex than expected
item.description:
An international team of astronomers has produced the clearest picture yet of the Milky Way's magnetic field, revealing a landscape of hidden complexity that challenges previous assumptions about our galaxy's invisible architecture.

The new map, created using data from the Dominion Radio Astrophysical Observatory near Penticton, British Columbia, shows that more than half of the northern sky contains intricate magnetic structures rather than the simple, uniform fields scientists once expected. The research, led by the University of British Columbia Okanagan, was published this week in The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series.
